title: R46113
content: This report analyzes annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2020, comparing enacted FY2019 appropriations, the Trump Administration's FY2020 budget request, and the enacted appropriations measures. It also provides additional informational resources on DHS appropriations and lists CRS policy experts for consultation. The CRS reports on homeland security appropriations track legislative action and congressional issues related to discretionary funding amounts. The curr_chunk discusses appropriations legislation related to DHS, focusing on discretionary funding amounts and specialized budgetary concepts. It does not analyze mandatory funding issues or other legislation related to DHS programs. The Appendix explains budgetary terms and the appropriations process. For more information, refer to CRS Report R42388. The curr_chunk provides detailed information on appropriations for homeland security, including budget authority, unrounded data calculations, and data sources for FY2019. It references the Budget Control Act, CRS Report R42388, and the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2019. The curr_chunk provides data on FY2019 appropriations for homeland security, sourced from P.L. 116-6 and two supplemental acts. It also includes FY2020 requested and House Appropriations Committee-recommended levels from H.Rept. 116-180. The curr_chunk provides data on FY2020 appropriations for homeland security, sourced from various congressional reports and acts. The scoring methodology is consistent and relies on data provided by the Appropriations Committees developed with Congressional Budget Office (CBO) methodology. Comparisons with Office of Management and Budget (OMB) data are not attempted due to technical scoring differences. The curr_chunk provides an overview of the legislative process for appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security for FY2020, sourced from Appropriations Committees with CBO methodology. OMB data on mandatory spending is no longer included in this report for consistency. The Trump Administration released its detailed budget request for FY2020 on March 18, 2019. The Trump Administration requested $51.68 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority for DHS for FY2020, representing a 4.6% increase from the previous year's appropriations. The Trump Administration requested a $2.27 billion increase in annual net discretionary budget authority for the Department of Homeland Security for FY2020. This includes funding for FEMA in disaster relief and Overseas Contingency Operations/Global War on Terror designated funding for the Coast Guard. The House Appropriations Committee marked up H.R. 3931, the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2020, which included $52.80 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority, $1.12 billion above the Administration's request. The bill also included $14.08 billion in disaster relief-designated funding and OCO funding from the Defense Appropriations bill. The House committee bill for FY2019 included $14.08 billion in disaster relief funding and OCO funding for the Coast Guard. Amendments in the full committee markup led to a CBO scoring exceeding the subcommittee allocation by $3 billion, later revised to $1.9 billion. The Senate Appropriations Committee marked up S. 2582 for the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2020, with $53.18 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority, $1.50 billion above the Administration's request. The Senate committee bill for FY2020 included $53.18 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority, $1.50 billion above the Administration's request. It also included increased funding for border barrier construction, Coast Guard, Transportation Security Administration, and FEMA. Additionally, the bill included $17.35 billion in disaster relief-designated funding and $190 million in OCO-designated funding for the Coast Guard. In late September 2019, Congress passed a continuing resolution (CR) to temporarily extend funding at the FY2019 rate for operations through November 21, subsequently extended through December 20. The CR included provisions addressing needs of DHS under a CR, such as special apportionment of funds for Secret Service expenses related to the FY2020 presidential campaign and an accelerated rate of apportionment for the Disaster Relief Fund. Section 133 of the FY2020 presidential campaign allows for an accelerated rate of apportionment for the Disaster Relief Fund (DRF) to ensure program funding. Section 134 extends authorization for the National Flood Insurance Program to issue new policies, while Section 135 allocates funds for a planned restructuring of some DHS management activities. Additionally, Section 101(6) extends immigration provisions linked to the appropriations cycle. Explanatory statements for two consolidated appropriations bills were released on the House Rules Committee website on December 16, 2019. One bill, using H.R. 1158 as a legislative shell, included the FY2020 DHS annual appropriations measure with $50.47 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority. The bill passed in the House by a vote of 280-138 on December 17 and in the Senate by a vote of 81-11 on December 19. It was signed into law on December 20, 2019. The FY2020 DHS annual appropriations bill included $190 million in Overseas Contingency Operations funding for the Coast Guard. It was passed by the House and Senate with votes of 280-138 and 81-11 respectively, and signed into law on December 20, 2019 as P.L. 116-93. The bill allocates resources to every departmental component of DHS, with discretionary appropriations making up the majority of funding. The Department of Homeland Security's funding includes fee revenues, trust funds, and mandatory spending. Appropriations for DHS are typically organized into five titles, with the first four grouping components thematically and the fifth providing general direction. Congress and the Administration initially used existing account structures for funding after DHS was established in 2003. In 2014, DHS began working on a new Common Appropriations Structure to standardize appropriations format. In 2014, DHS started developing a new Common Appropriations Structure (CAS) to standardize appropriations format. The CAS aimed to streamline over 70 different appropriations and over 100 Programs, Projects, and Activities to enhance transparency and simplify spending decisions. After negotiations with Congress, DHS implemented the CAS in its budget request for FY2017, converting legacy appropriations structures into four categories: Operations and Support, Procurement, Construction, and Improvements. The Common Appropriations Structure (CAS) was implemented by DHS in its budget request for FY2017, converting legacy appropriations structures into four categories: Operations and Support, Procurement, Construction, and Improvements, Research and Development, and Federal Assistance. Operations and Support cover operating salaries and expenses, Procurement, Construction, and Improvements fund planning and deployment of assets, Research and Development identify new technologies, and Federal Assistance supports grant funding managed by DHS components. The Federal Protective Service and USCG's Retired Pay are two appropriations not included in the CAS structure. The FPS account allows funds to be spent as needed, while the USCG's Retired Pay covers costs for retired personnel entitlements. The USCG's Retired Pay appropriation supports retired personnel entitlements, including pensions, Survivor Benefits Plans, and medical care. It is categorized as appropriated mandatory spending and does not count against discretionary allocation. FEMA receives a separate appropriation for disaster relief activities authorized under the Stafford Act. FEMA receives separate appropriations for its disaster relief activities under the Stafford Act, allowing for consistent tracking of spending and transparency. The National Flood Insurance Program has mandatory spending but certain functions are funded through discretionary appropriations and fees collected by the government. Certain program costs related to floodplain management, flood mapping, and flood insurance operations are funded through discretionary appropriations and fees collected by the government. Funding for law enforcement operational components in the Department of Homeland Security is generally provided in Title II of the annual appropriations act. This includes agencies like U.S. Customs and Border Protection, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Transportation Security Administration, and U.S. Coast Guard, each with specific responsibilities for securing borders, preventing terrorism, and ensuring transportation security. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) provides security for the U.S. transportation system, while the U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) is responsible for maritime safety and security in U.S. ports. The U.S. Secret Service (USSS) protects the President, Vice-President, and other designated individuals and locations. The U.S. Secret Service (USSS) protects key individuals and locations, investigates financial crimes, and enforces counterfeiting laws. For more on FY2020 DHS appropriations, refer to CRS reports R45972, R44604, and R44052. The FY2020 DHS appropriations involved a multistep process of budget authority, obligations, and outlays. Budget authority is enacted by Congress, funds are obligated for activities, and payments are made to liquidate obligations. Congressional clients can consult CRS experts for more information on DHS appropriations. Budget authority is established through appropriations acts or direct spending legislation and determines the amounts available for federal agencies to spend. The Antideficiency Act prohibits agencies from obligating more funds than enacted by Congress. Budget authority may be indefinite or available on a one-year, multiyear, or no-year basis. Budget authority can be one-year, multiyear, or no-year. One-year funds must be spent within that fiscal year, while multiyear and no-year funds can be spent over a longer period. Obligations are incurred when agencies make contracts or receive services, creating a legal requirement to pay. Outlays are the actual funds spent in a fiscal year, which may not always match the budget authority. Funds can be obligated in one year but spent in a future year. Budget authority allows federal agencies to incur obligations and authorize payments from the Treasury. It includes discretionary and mandatory spending, with discretionary funds appropriated yearly by Congress. Gross budget authority is the total funds available for spending, composed of discretionary and mandatory spending. The Budget Enforcement Act of 1990 distinguishes between discretionary and mandatory spending. Discretionary spending is annually appropriated by Congress, while mandatory spending is provided in laws outside of appropriations acts. Some mandatory entitlement programs require yearly appropriations, such as Coast Guard retirement pay within DHS. Offset funds are collected by the government through business transactions. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) distinguishes between discretionary and mandatory spending. Coast Guard retirement pay is an example of appropriated mandatory spending within DHS. Offset funds collected by the government are not considered federal revenue but are counted as negative outlays. DHS net discretionary budget authority is composed of discretionary spending minus any fee or fund collections that offset discretionary spending. The DHS budget includes mandatory entitlement programs like the Secret Service and Coast Guard retired pay accounts. Secret Service retirement pay is a permanent appropriation, while Coast Guard retirement pay is annually appropriated. Additionally, the DHS budget contains offsetting Trust and Public Enterprise Funds, which are not appropriated by Congress but are included in the President's budget to calculate gross budget authority. The DHS budget includes offsetting Trust and Public Enterprise Funds that are not appropriated by Congress but are included in the President's budget to calculate gross budget authority. The maximum budget authority for annual appropriations, including DHS, is determined through a two-stage congressional budget process involving 302(a) and 302(b) allocations. The 302(a) allocations are discretionary totals available to the Committees on Appropriations for annual appropriations bills. The appropriations committees then allocate the 302(a) funds among subcommittees for each bill as 302(b) allocations. These allocations must not exceed the 302(a) allocation to enforce budget discipline. Adjustments to 302(b) allocations can be made during the year as bills progress. These provisions were not included in the final FY2020 DHS appropriations act. The Budget Control Act established enforceable discretionary limits for defense and nondefense spending. Adjustments can be made to cover funding for overseas operations, emergency spending, disaster relief, and health care fraud control. The Budget Control Act allows for adjustments to statutory caps to fund overseas operations, emergency spending, disaster relief, and health care fraud control. Adjustments are determined by the Office of Management and Budget based on a formula involving a rolling average of disaster relief spending over the last ten fiscal years. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018 amended the formula for disaster relief cap adjustments, increasing the allowable size by adding 5% of emergency-designated funding for major disasters under the Stafford Act. OMB released a sequestration preview report for FY2020 estimating an allowable adjustment of $17.5 billion, the second-largest in history. In August 2019, OMB released a sequestration preview report for FY2020 estimating an allowable adjustment of $17.5 billion, the second-largest in history. This estimate includes the 10-year average, 5% of emergency-designated Stafford Act spending since 2012, and carryover from the previous year. The final adjustment for FY2020 may still vary from this estimate.
